text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Egypt intensifies efforts to support the peace process as Europe tries to set up a meeting between Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and Israel's Foreign Minister David Levy.
- Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and King Hassan of Morocco are expected to sign an agreement in December to establish a free trade zone.
- The recent tariff amendments aim to protect local production in the car industry.
- Public Enterprise Minister Atef Obeid and Arab investors in the United States have discussed setting up three joint agricultural projects which aim to export up to 90 percent of their output.
- Supply and Trade Minister Ahmed Gueily says that the government aims to protect consumers in Egypt and make available appropriate prices.
- U.S. Senate agrees to give Egypt aid worth $2.1 billion for 1998.

- The volume of American investment in Egypt has reached 11.4 billion pounds, says Ibrahim Fawzy of the General Authority for Investment. The United States' participation in 212 projects with a combined capital of 5.5 billion pounds makes it the largest investor in Egypt.
- Agricultural banks decided to finance purchases of land by farmers who are currently renting from landowners, and a committee was formed to look after such loans.
- International Monetary Fund says Egypt's economic reform programme has exceeded expectations. Long term foreign direct investment as opposed to short term must be encouraged.
- Mubarak will open a Nubian museum in October which will house 5,000 artefacts portraying the life of the Nubian people.
